was a time when this the most arctic of the <s>terrestrial<\s> Ruminants, 
<s>Mammalia<\s> ranged far south of its present abode 
and left it bones in the gravels and brick<s>pits<\s>earths as a 
proof of its former presence in Northern Asia, Central 
and Western Europe. Also in a fossil state in America 
two closely allies forms have been found, the two 
species of Bootherium (1) of Prof. Leidy 1, Its range in 
space and time and its relation to these two animals, are 
questions <s>of the<\s> which fall within the scope of this 
essay. 
Natural history 2. The Ovibos Moschatus about equals in 
size the small Welsh and Scotch cattle. The head is large 
and broad, and the nostrils are oblong inclining towards 
each other from above downwards, with inner margins 
naked and united for half an inch at their base. 
The rest of the end of the nose, the middle part of the 
upper lip, and the greater part of the lower lip and chin 
are covered with close short white hairs; the upper lip 
is furrowless, and there is no trace of a muffle. These 
points alone would be sufficient to separate the animals 
from the Bos and the Bubalus and relegate it to the <s>Caprine 
and<\s> Ovine group of Mammals. The <s>eyes are<\s> ears are small 
as in the Yak being three inches in length, erect and pointed, 
dilated in the middle. The dark umberbrown hair on
